title-group.article-title: Comorbidity and Phenomenology of Bipolar Disorder in Children With ADHD

abstract.p: Objective: To assess the comorbidity of bipolar disorder (BPD) in children with ADHD and to study the psychopathological profile of ADHD children with and without mania. Method: A total of 100 children with ADHD were assessed with a semistructured diagnostic interview and questionnaires of mania, ADHD, and general psychopathology. Results: 8% of children met criteria for BPD and 6% for BPD–not specified. ADHD children with bipolar spectrum disorder had greater comorbidity with disruptive behavior disorders and scored higher on the Young Mania Rating Scales and on the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL) Scales of rule-breaking behavior, externalizing problems, and total problems; however, significance on the CBCL Scales was lost when controlling for disruptive behavior disorders. Conclusion: BPD is frequently associated with ADHD; it has important implications for prognosis and choice of treatment. Differences on the CBCL Scales could be explained by the comorbidity with disruptive behavior disorders rather than by a specific manic profile.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Comorbidity of ADHD with bipolar disorder (BPD) in children is a controversial issue because of the difficulty diagnosing pediatric mania and the possible overlap of symptoms between both disorders. The clinical presentation of BPD in pre- and early adolescence is widely debated. The National Institute of Mental Health Research Roundtable on Prepubertal Bipolar Disorder (2001) agreed that pediatric BPD could manifest itself as “narrow” and “broad” phenotypes. Children and adolescents with the “narrow” phenotype have recurrent periods of major depression and mania or hypomania, as defined in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (4th ed.; DSM-IV) for BPD Type I or Type II (American Psychiatric Association [APA], 1994). Most of these children experience multiple episodes with rapid cycling (Findling et al., 2001; Geller et al., 2002). In contrast, children with the “broad” phenotype have severe irritability, “affective storms,” mood lability, temper tantrums, symptoms of depression, anxiety, hyperactivity, poor concentration and impulsivity, and a not clearly episodic course (Biederman et al., 1996). Other authors have suggested a phenotypic system of juvenile BPD, based on the presence of defined episodes and hallmark symptoms (Leibenluft, Charney, Towbin, Bhangoo, & Pine, 2003).

Several investigations in the United States have studied comorbidity between both disorders in children. In a sample of children and adolescents with ADHD, Biederman et al. (1996) found that 11% had BPD at baseline and another 12% at the 4-year follow-up. Butler, Arredondo, and McCloskey (1995) found a 22% rate of comorbidity with mania in a sample of hospitalized ADHD children. In a sample of children below 12 years with ADHD, Wozniak et al. (1995) found a 20% rate of comorbidity with BPD. In studies by Wozniak et al. (1995) and Biederman et al. (1996), severe irritability rather than euphoria was the predominant mood symptom in the children meeting criteria for mania, and, thus, these children were considered as having “broad” phenotype BPD.

Outside the United States, similar researches have only been conducted with the Turkish population; these studies show lower prevalence rates (8.2%, Diler, Uguz, Seydaoglu, Erol, & Avci, 2007; and 8.3%, Lus & Mukaddes, 2009). To diagnose BPD, children had to meet the criteria for the “narrow” phenotype described by Leibenluft et al. (2003). Thus, in addition to meeting DSM-IV criteria for mania and hypomania, patients had to exhibit the hallmark symptom of elevated mood and/or grandiosity. As a result, the lower percentage of prevalence of BPD in children with ADHD in the two Turkish studies could be explained by the use of more restrictive criteria for diagnosing BPD.

The lack of consensus on the definition and assessment of BPD in children has been regarded as the greatest impediment to the study and treatment of the disorder (Mick, Biederman, Pandina, & Faraone, 2003). In this respect, some authors have suggested that the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL; Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001), as it is a tool for parents, could offer an unbiased approach to detecting children and adolescents with BPD (Althoff, Rettew, Faraone, Boomsma, & Hudziak, 2006; Faraone, Althoff, Hudziak, Monuteaux, & Biederman, 2005; Hudziak, Althoff, Derks, Faraone, & Boomsma, 2005). Mick et al. (2003) in a meta-analysis concluded that children with mania had a consistent pattern of high scores (T ≥ 70; 2 SD) on the Anxious-Depressed, Aggressive Behavior, and Attention Problems Scales. This profile has been referred to as CBCL–pediatric bipolar disorder (CBCL-PBD; Mick et al., 2003). Some studies have suggested the utility of the CBCL-PBD profile for predicting pediatric BPD and related problems (Biederman et al., 2009; Faraone et al., 2005). Other studies, however, concluded that the CBCL-PBD profile is not associated with the diagnosis of BPD in children but is associated with disruptive behavior disorders (Holtmann, Goth, Wockel, Poustka, & Bolte, 2008; Youngstrom, Youngstrom, & Starr, 2005) and severe attention problems (Hudziak et al., 2005). Meyer et al. (2009) in a longitudinal study found low diagnostic efficiency for BPD in children with the CBCL-PBD profile. The results showed that children with the CBCL-PBD profile are at risk for ongoing, severe, psychiatric symptomatology, including behavior and emotional comorbidities.

Previous studies indicate that the comorbidity of BPD in ADHD is associated with greater functional impairment, greater comorbidity with anxiety, disruptive behavior disorders, and a psychopathological profile characterized by increased externalizing problems, anxious/depressed, social problems, and thought problems (Biederman et al., 1996; Diler et al., 2007; Mick et al., 2003; Wozniak et al., 1995).

Studies on pediatric BPD primarily come from samples from the United States; the only two studies outside the United States that examined the comorbidity of mania in ADHD were conducted on Turkish children with “narrow” phenotype BPD. The objectives of this study were three: First, to assess comorbidity with BPD both according to DSM-IV criteria and according to a broad spectrum BPD in children and adolescents with ADHD. Second, to study the differences in the psychopathological profile—severity of hyperactive-impulsive, attention deficit, and mania symptoms—in ADHD children with and without BPD, and thus to verify whether some symptoms may help in differential diagnosis. Third, to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of the CBCL-PBD to identify BPD in children and adolescents with ADHD.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 100 children and adolescents between 8 and 17 years of age (M = 11.03; SD = 2.61 years), consecutively referred to outpatient child and adolescent psychiatry and psychology units of three hospitals (two within the public health network and one private) in Barcelona, participated in the study. Inclusion criteria required participants to have a principal diagnosis of ADHD according to DSM-IV criteria (APA, 1994) assessed with the Diagnostic Interview for Children and Adolescents-IV (DICA-IV; Reich, 2000). Table 1 shows the demographic and clinical characteristics of the sample. In all, 30% of the parents had a high occupational status (professionals and executives), 35% had an average occupational status (skilled workers), 32% had a low occupational status (unskilled workers and manual laborers), and 3% were unemployed.

sec.p: Those participants who had a previous diagnosis of mental retardation, pervasive developmental disorder, schizophrenia, or severe neurological disorders were excluded.

sec.title: DICA-IV
sec.p: The DICA-IV (Reich, 2000) is a semistructured diagnostic interview that assesses a wide range of psychological disorders in children and adolescents based on diagnostic criteria from the DSM-IV (APA, 1994). The Spanish version of the DICA-IV has been adapted and validated for the Spanish population with satisfactory psychometric properties (Ezpeleta, Osa, Doménech, Navarro, & Losilla, 1997; Osa, Ezpeleta, Doménech, Navarro, & Losilla, 1996). The following sections were used: ADHD, oppositional defiant disorder (ODD), conduct disorder (CD), and mania. The diagnoses were established by combining the information provided by parents and children/adolescents for each symptom. The symptom was considered present if the parents or child/adolescent referred to it in the interview. For this study, the same clinician administered the DICA-IV to the parents and to the child/adolescent, independently considering the information provided by each one.

In addition to the DSM-IV diagnosis of BPD (BPD-DSM), BPD–not otherwise specified (BPD-NOS) was defined based on criteria set out by Birmaher et al. (2006), such as the presence of relevant BPD symptoms that do not meet DSM-IV criteria for BPD. Specifically, participants needed to have (a) elated mood and two associated DSM-IV symptoms or irritable mood and three associated DSM-IV symptoms, (b) a change in the level of functioning, (c) duration of a minimum of 4 hr within a 24-hr period, and (d) at least four cumulative lifetime days meeting the criteria. Previous studies have showed that children meeting these more strictly defined BPD-NOS criteria have similar, but less severe, clinical pictures, comorbid disorders, family history, and longitudinal outcome than the BPD Type I participants (Axelson et al., 2006; Birmaher et al., 2006). Moreover, about 25% of these youth diagnosed with BPD-NOS converted into BPD Type I or BPD Type II (Birmaher et al., 2006).

Bipolar spectrum disorder (BP-SD) was used to refer to the group of ADHD children consisting of BPD-DSM + BPD-NOS. We used without mania (wMAN) to refer to ADHD children without comorbidity with BP-SD.

sec.title: Young Mania Rating Scale (YMRS)
sec.p: This is an 11-item scale developed by Young, Biggs, Ziegler, and Meyer (1978) to be completed by the clinician while interviewing the patient. Validation studies with outpatient pediatric populations have obtained satisfactory psychometric properties (Fristad, Weller, & Weller, 1992, 1995; Youngstrom, Danielson, Findling, Gracious, & Calabrese, 2002). In this sample, Serrano, Ezpeleta, Alda, Matali, and San (2011) validated the YMRS for children and adolescents with ADHD and showed good internal consistency and ability to discriminate between ADHD with and without mania (wMAN).

sec.title: Parent-YMRS (P-YMRS)
sec.p: Developed by Gracious, Youngstrom, Findling, and Calabrese (2002), it is the parent version of the YMRS. The original version of the P-YMRS showed adequate reliability and discriminant validity between BPD and unipolar disorder, disruptive behavior disorders, and any other diagnosis (Gracious et al., 2002). The Catalan version, which obtained adequate internal consistency (Cronbach’s α = .71) for this sample, was used.

sec.title: Child Mania Rating Scale–Parent Version (CMRS-P)
sec.p: It was developed by Pavuluri, Henry, Devineni, Carbray, and Birmaher (2006) to screen for child mania. It consists of 21 items that are answered by parents and is based on DSM-IV symptoms for manic episode. The original version of the CMRS-P differentiated between children with mania and children with ADHD (Pavuluri et al., 2006). The Spanish version of the CMRS-P obtained good internal consistency (Cronbach’s α = .91) for this sample.

sec.title: Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL)
sec.p: The CBCL (Achenbach et al., 2001) assesses psychopathology in children and adolescents aged 6 to 18. It consists of 113 items and assesses emotional and behavioral problems based on the opinion of parents. The CBCL has been adapted and studied in the Spanish population (Sardinero, Pedreira, & Muñiz, 1997). According to previous studies (Faraone et al., 2005; Mick et al., 2003), the CBCL-PBD profile has been defined as the sum of the CBCL Anxious/Depressed, Attention Problems, and Aggressive Behavior Scales. The cutoff point of the CBCL-PBD for mania is 210 (sum of T-scores ≥ 70 on the scales that conform with the CBCL-PBD).

sec.title: Conners’ Parents Rating Scale (CPRS-48)
sec.p: This is a scale developed by Conners (1989) to assess symptoms characteristic of ADHD. The CPRS-48 consists of 48 items; the parents must rate the frequency of their child’s behavior for each item.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Once written consent to participate in the study was obtained from parents and adolescents (above 12 years) and verbal consent was obtained from children (below 12 years), the parents and the children were interviewed separately with the DICA-IV. The examination concluded with parents completing the P-YMRS, the CMRS-P, the CBCL, and the CPRS-48 and the clinician completing the YMRS. This research was approved by the ethics committee of the institution.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: The data were analyzed using SPSS 17.0. Student’s t test was used to compare age and scores on the CBCL and CPRS-48 scales by diagnostic group. Multiple linear regression analysis controlling for sex, age, and comorbidity with disruptive behavior disorders was used to analyze the association between CBCL and CPRS-48 Scales and the diagnosis of BP-SD. Sex distribution, ADHD type, comorbidity, and frequency of mania and ADHD symptoms by diagnostic group were analyzed using Fisher’s exact test. The McNemar test was used to study the distribution of symptoms by diagnostic group among informants. The relationship between scores on the Mania Scales and on the CBCL-PBD profile with the BP-SD diagnosis was evaluated using multiple linear regression analysis controlling for sex, age, and comorbidity with ODD and CD. All tests were two tailed.

sec.title: Comorbidity With BPD (Manic Episode)
sec.p: Among the 100 children and adolescents with ADHD, 8 (8%) met criteria for BPD according to DSM-IV (BPD-DSM) and 6 (6%) were diagnosed with BPD-NOS. In sum, 14 (14%) children and adolescents with ADHD had an associated bipolar spectrum disorder (BP-SD). Of this group, 10 (71.43%) cases had episodes of euphoric or expansive mood. Irritability was found in 100% of the children with BP-SD, and in 4 cases (28.57%), irritability was the criterion for abnormal mood, without euphoric or expansive mood. All these cases belonged to the BPD-NOS group.

The average age of onset of mania in the BP-SD group was 11 years (SD = 4). No significant differences were found in sex between the wMAN and the BP-SD groups (Table 1). The group with mania was significantly older than the group wMAN.
The BP-SD group had significantly greater comorbidity with ODD and CD than the wMAN group.

sec.title: CBCL and CBCL-PBD Profile by Diagnostic Group
sec.p: The BP-SD group obtained higher scores than the wMAN group on the CBCL Scales of Rule-Breaking Behavior, Externalizing Problems, and Total Problems (Figure 1). After adjusting for sex, age, and comorbidity with ODD and CD, the multiple linear regression analysis showed that none of the scales of CBCL were significantly associated with the diagnosis of BP-SD.

caption.p: Comparison of mean Child Behavior Checklist scores among ADHD children with bipolar spectrum disorder (BP-SD) and without mania (wMAN; p Student’s t test).

sec.p: The CBCL-PBD profile was present in 18 participants (18%). Of this group, 2 (11.1%) cases were diagnosed with BPD-DSM (sensitivity = 25%; specificity = 82.6%). No patient diagnosed with BPD-NOS had the CBCL-PBD profile.

The multiple linear regression analysis controlling for sex, age, and comorbidity with ODD and CD showed that the CBCL-PBD profile was not significantly associated with the diagnosis of BP-SD (B = -0.1, 95% confidence interval [-0.3-0.1]; Table 1).

sec.title: Dimensional symptoms
sec.p: The multiple linear regression analysis controlling for sex, age, and comorbidity with ODD and CD showed that the total score on the YMRS was higher in the BP-SD group than in the wMAN group. The same analysis showed that the total score on the P-YMRS and on the CMRS-P, which are scales assessing mania completed by the parents, did not differ by diagnostic group (Table 1).

sec.title: Categorical symptoms
sec.p: Table 2 shows the presence of DSM-IV mania symptoms assessed with the DICA-IV in each diagnostic group separately for the information from parents and children.

sec.p: The BP-SD group significantly presented higher frequency than the wMAN group in all mania symptoms, whether the informant was the child/adolescent or the parents. There were no differences in either group when comparing mania symptoms reported by parents and children. The exception was increase in goal-directed activity- psychomotor agitation, which was more frequently reported in the wMAN group when the informant was the parent than when the informant was the child.

sec.title: Dimensional symptoms
sec.p: There were no significant differences by diagnostic group in the severity of ADHD symptoms assessed by scales of the CPRS-48 (Figure 2). After adjusting for sex, age, and comorbidity with ODD and CD, the multiple linear regression analysis did not show significant association with the diagnosis of BP-SD.

sec.p: Children in the BP-SD group reported a significantly greater proportion of the hyperactive-impulsive type symptoms—squirms in seat, runs about or climbs excessively, has difficulty playing quietly, often acts as if driven by a motor and blurts out answers—than the wMAN children. Parents of the BP-SD children and the wMAN children reported a similar frequency of ADHD symptoms (the exception was does not seem to listen when spoken to directly, for which there was a higher frequency in the wMAN group).

The percentages of all ADHD symptoms reported by the parents were significantly higher than those reported by the children in the wMAN group (except often acts as if driven by a motor and talks excessively). In the BP-SD group, the parents significantly reported a greater percentage of the inattention symptoms has difficulty organizing tasks and activities and loses things.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The first finding from our study is the frequent association between ADHD and BPD in children and adolescents; we found an association of 8% for BPD-DSM and of 6% for BPD-NOS, resulting in a total comorbidity with BP-SD of 14%. These data on the prevalence of BPD-DSM are very similar to those found in other studies on the Turkish population (Diler et al., 2007; Lus et al., 2009) using the “narrow” phenotype. In our study, all patients diagnosed with BPD-DSM had elevated mood and/or grandiosity; therefore, they would be considered to have the “narrow” phenotype. BP-SD rates were not very different from those found by Biederman et al. (1996) in their cross-sectional study, but they were clearly lower than those found in other studies in the United States (Butler et al., 1995; Wozniak et al., 1995). In the study by Butler et al. (1995), the children with ADHD were hospitalized, their psychiatric symptoms were expected to be more severe, and, accordingly, there was a greater risk of manifesting associated BPD. In the Wozniak et al. (1995) and in Biederman et al., 1996 studies, irritability was the predominant mood symptom in children diagnosed with BPD and thus considered as “broad” phenotype. In our study, irritable mood (without elevated mood and/or grandiosity) was found in approximately one third of the cases of BP-SD. All cases were diagnosed with BPD-NOS.

Children with mania were significantly older than those wMAN; the average age at onset of mania was 11. Diler et al. (2007) and Lus et al. (2009) reported an average age of onset of BPD in children with ADHD of 9.2 and 8.9 years, respectively. Biederman et al. (2004) found the youngest age of onset (6.3 years). These differences between studies could be explained by the clinical characteristics of the sample in terms of the BPD phenotype. Children with the “broad” phenotype, such as the sample in Biederman’s study, have severe irritability, aggression, and temper outbursts, which are symptoms that have been related to the initial symptoms of prepubertal onset of BPD (Lázaro et al., 2007).

A second finding was that children with ADHD and BPD have higher comorbidity with ODD and CD and a psychopathological profile characterized by higher scores on the CBCL Scales of Rule-Breaking Behavior, Externalizing Problems, and Total Problems. However, when adjusted for sex, age, and comorbidity with disruptive behavior disorders, none of the scales of the CBCL were associated with BP-SD. Thus, with adjustments, children with ADHD and BPD do not present a specific profile characterized by increased externalizing problems. Previous studies, without any adjustments, found that children with ADHD and BPD have a psychopathological profile characterized by higher scores on the CBCL Scales of Anxiety/Depression, Social Problems, Thought Problems, and Aggression (Biederman et al., 1996; Diler et al., 2007; Lus et al., 2009). Regarding internalizing problems, these are similar in ADHD children with mania and wMAN.

A third finding was that the CBCL-PBD profile is not a useful tool for identifying BPD in children with ADHD. Lus et al. (2009) in an ADHD sample found that the CBCL-PBD has a low predictive validity (18%) for detecting BPD. However, Faraone et al. (2005) found that the CBCL-PBD profile made it possible to determine BPD in ADHD. This discrepancy could be explained by the differences in the clinical characteristics of the samples. Accordingly, the CBCL-PBD profile may be appropriate for some patients with ADHD characterized by severe ADHD symptoms with high comorbidity (CD and mood disorders), as could be the case with Faraone’s sample; nonetheless, it does not properly detect BPD in other samples (perhaps more generally within the ADHD population), as might be the case with the Turkish sample (Diler et al., 2007; Lus et al., 2009) and with our sample.

The fourth finding was that the scores on the YMRS were different in children with mania and wMAN. However, when the informants were the parents, none of the mania scales were able to differentiate BPD in ADHD. Previous studies argued that parents are valid but imperfect informants when reporting on conduct problems (Youngstrom, Loeber, & Stouthamer-Loeber, 2000), emotions (Youngstrom, Izard, & Ackerman, 1999), and cognitive ability (Waschbusch, Daleiden, & Drabman, 2000).

The BP-SD group significantly obtained a higher proportion in all DSM symptoms for mania, whether the informant was the child/adolescent or the parents. From the findings in this study, we can conclude that children with ADHD are good informants for assessing the presence of manic symptoms.

The fifth finding was that children with ADHD and BPD do not have more severe ADHD symptoms, using the CPRS-48 and parents’ information of categorical symptoms. Along these lines, Fristad et al. (1992) found that children with mania and children with ADHD received similar scores on the Conners’ Rating Scale, whereas manic children scored significantly higher than ADHD children on the Mania Rating Scale. However, Biederman et al. (1996) found more severe ADHD symptoms in patients with comorbid BPD. By contrast, BP-SD children recognize significantly more ADHD symptoms than do wMAN children. The higher age of the former group could be involved in a better recognition of symptoms.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: The study poses some limitations resulting from the limited number of participants to study subgroups according to comorbidity with BD-SD. The sample size of the ADHD group with BPD should be increased in future studies. Another limitation was caused by the fact that the same clinician completed the YMRS and gave the DICA-IV interview to parents and children for the diagnosis, and was therefore not blind, which could cause bias in the assessment. However, this possibility was tested and, as regards the BPD-DSM group, there were no significant differences in the scores of the clinicians (YMRS), who knew the diagnoses, and those of the parents (P-YMRS), who did not know the diagnoses (p = .061), which consequently refutes a bias in the clinicians’ ratings. Furthermore, in other interviews, like the Kiddie Schedule for Affective Disorders and Schizophrenia for School-Age Children (K-SADS), it is established that the same interviewer assesses both the parents and the child.

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Eduardo Serrano, MSc, is a psychologist at the ADHD unit, child and adolescent psychiatry and psychology department, Hospital Sant Joan de Déu, Barcelona. He is currently working on a PhD degree at the unit of epidemiology and diagnostic in developmental psychopathology, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona.

Lourdes Ezpeleta, PhD, is a clinical psychologist. She is professor of Child and Adolescent Psychopathology. She is also director of the unit of epidemiology and diagnostic in developmental psychopathology, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona.

Josefina Castro-Fornieles, PhD, is a psychiatry specialist. She is head of the child and adolescent psychiatry and psychology department, Centro de Investigación Biomédica en Red de Salud Mental Research Network, Hospital Clínic Universitari of Barcelona. She is also professor of psychiatry, faculty of medicine, Universitat de Barcelona.
